title: Hate crimes are growing and abusers are getting away with it
text:
Non-disabled people shouldn’t underestimate how hearing these horrid words can make you feel (Picture: Joshua Reeves)

They say that sticks and stones may break my bones, but names will never hurt me. But they do – that saying is a lie.

This week, the international disability charity, Leonard Cheshire, found that in 2018/19 disability hate crime rose by 22 per cent.

I’m one of the people who have experienced hate crime and I want to make sure everyone understands how damaging it can be.

I was on the receiving end of verbal abuse in a space that I thought was safe; I was online gaming in the comfort of my own home.

What happened to me was this: A person joined our party online, appearing nice to me and my friends. But as soon as he realised I had a disability he wanted a private chat and started using words like ‘spaz’ and ‘cripple’ to offend me.

Advertisement

Advertisement

This came completely out of the blue and I felt hurt. But I doubt I’m the only disabled person to have abuse strike when you’re least expecting it.

Non-disabled people shouldn’t underestimate how hearing these horrid words can make you feel. I’ve spoken with disabled people who have suffered from ongoing abuse and they’ll tell you, no matter how many times these names are thrown at you, it doesn’t get any less hurtful.

When it happened to me I felt embarrassed and weak. I have no idea who said this to me from behind their screen, but I think they are cruel and cowardly.

I want to know why people hate others because of disability. I’m sure that this earth was made for us to love one another and look after our fellow humans, not hurt them.

Calling someone a ‘cripple,’ ‘spaz’ or ‘retard’ because they are disabled is offensive and should be taken more seriously by law enforcers

I’ve run hate crime workshops and have seen the impact hate crime can have, whether it is online or in real life, verbal or violent.

People lose their confidence and become afraid to leave their homes. For me, it was important to take my experience and talk about it, reaching out to others.

I found it empowering to take this horrible experience and turn it on its head. I thought to myself, ‘I have a voice, I should inspire other people to speak out and report what they’ve experienced to the police.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

But unfortunately, although 5,000 disability hate crimes were reported to the police last year, only six per cent were sent to the Crown Prosecution Service or received a charge or summons.

And that’s not even accounting for the people who were too afraid to report to the police in the first place.

Calling someone a ‘cripple,’ ‘spaz’ or ‘retard’ because they are disabled is offensive and should be taken more seriously by law enforcers. And when it’s online, we need the big cyber companies to do more.

I didn’t feel like what I experienced was taken seriously when I reported it to the tech company in question – and it wasn’t easy to report in the first place.

Given that many people feel too scared to report and that reporting procedures are often inaccessible, it goes without saying that more needs to be done.

My experience of hate crime on a gaming platform is only one of many similar stories. Online hate crime rose by 71 per cent in the past year, which is no doubt a depressing statistic.

And life offline can be even scarier, with an increase in physical assault (a shocking 92 per cent of police forces reported increasing violence).

These findings should make everyone sit up and think about how unsafe disabled people must feel.

This is why I continue to speak to other disabled people about the hate crime we have experienced. Through these conversations I’m learning that it happens everywhere.

Advertisement

Disabled people need to have the confidence to report it and the knowledge that the police will act on protecting them from the criminals who did this to them.

I hope sharing my story will help other people who have experienced this injustice feel less alone and that their concerns are serious.

It is never ‘only’ online, or ‘only’ verbal. Hate crime is hate crime and nobody should be allowed to get away with it.
